nodes.text: Economists' empirical estimates of economic damages from climate change severely underestimate true risks and the widely used integrated assessment models (notably DICE) calibrated to them are unreliable for policy
Economists misrepresent the scientific literature on climate tipping points, treating them as unlikely within this century
Scientific assessments (Lenton et al. 2008 and follow-ups) identify multiple climate tipping elements plausibly triggerable this century and potential tipping cascades that amplify impacts
Nordhaus and DICE documentation cite and reinterpret Lenton et al. to justify excluding tipping points from damage functions, a misrepresentation of that scientific work

A central methodological error in many economic damage studies is equating 'affected by climate change' with 'directly exposed to weather', thereby excluding most sectors (manufacturing, services, government) from damages
Nordhaus 1991 sectoral breakdown labeled about 87% of US output as 'negligible effect' because activities occur in 'controlled environments', used to omit large sectors from damage accounting

The omission is invalid because climate impacts (wildfires, floods, livability thresholds, disrupted inputs like energy, agriculture, minerals) affect indoor and supply-chain dependent sectors and can halt production
A second common error is using spatial cross-sectional relations between current regional temperature and income as a proxy for temporal global warming impacts

Empirical evidence shows the spatial temperature-income fit is weak, confounded by trade, historical adaptation, soil and topsoil constraints, and cannot capture new extremes or tipping-driven changes in climate patterns
DICE is built on a Ramsey growth framework with Cobb-Douglas production, exogenous labor and productivity growth, full employment, and abatement costs that are treated as pure economic costs

Structural features of DICE (saddle-path stability, exogenous TFP and labor, production function lacking environmental inputs, assumption of full employment) make it incapable of producing economic collapse as an equilibrium outcome

Sensitivity simulations of DICE increasing damage convexity and magnitude produce corner solutions (immediate full mitigation), extreme abatement burdens, deep temporary consumption and capital drops but eventual recovery; collapse is not produced except when solver infeasibility occurs at unrealistically extreme damage coefficients

Post-2014 studies and expert elicitation that incorporate tipping probabilities or use alternative empirical approaches produce much larger damage estimates and higher social cost of carbon (including estimates that increase SCC by factors >8 when tipping is included)

Epistemological and refereeing norms in mainstream economics (Friedman-style tolerance of unrealistic assumptions, tight author networks) enabled publication and persistence of flawed methods and data in the literature

Given misrepresented science, methodological errors, and DICE's structural inability to model collapse, economists' empirical damage estimates and models calibrated to them (e.g. DICE, FUND, PAGE) should not be used to evaluate climate risks or set policy

Policy and assessment should prioritize science-based approaches that incorporate tipping points, systemic supply-chain impacts, realistic damage functions, and models able to represent non-equilibrium collapse risks
